case_name: Firestone Tyre and Rubber Co. of India Ltd. v. its workmen

facts.text: Two appeals arise from an industrial dispute between Firestone Tyre and Rubber Co. of India Ltd. (company) and its workmen (respondents).

anchor.surface_text: Gajendragadkar, J. These two appeals arise from an industrial dispute between the Firestone Tyre and Rubber Co. of India Ltd.,  hereafter called the companypany  and its workmen  hereafter called the respondents , and they raise a short and interesting question about the companystruction of s. 12 5  of the Industrial Disputes Act 14 of 1947  hereafter called the Act .

facts.text: Respondents addressed four demands to the company: gratuity, holidays, classification of certain employees, and payment of unconditional bonus for financial year ended October 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the respondents addressed four demands to the companypany they were in respect of gratuity, holidays, classification of certain employees and for the payment of an unconditional bonus for the financial year ended October 31, 1953.

facts.text: Respondents' union addressed Assistant Commissioner of Labour, Bombay, forwarding copy of demands, stating no hope of direct negotiations as company had not recognised the union.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents union also addressed the Assistant Commissioner of Labour, Bombay, forwarding to him a companyy of the said demands, and intimating to him that since the companypany had number recognised the respondents union there was numberhope of any direct negotiations between the union and the companypany.

facts.text: Assistant Commissioner of Labour (conciliation officer) requested to commence conciliation proceedings early.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Commissioner of Labour, who is also the companyciliation officer, was therefore requested to companymence the companyciliation proceedings at an early date.

facts.text: Company declared bonus equivalent to 1/4 of basic earnings for year 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: Soon thereafter the companypany declared a bonus equivalent to 1/4 of the basic earnings for the year 1952-53.

facts.text: Respondents informed company entitled to higher bonus re profits, accepted offered bonus without prejudice to demand.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then informed the companypany that they were entitled to a much higher bonus having regard to the profits made by the companypany during the relevant year and that they had decided to accept the bonus offered by the companypany without prejudice to the demand already submitted by them in that behalf.

facts.text: Conciliation officer admitted into conciliation only two demands: classification of certain employees and bonus for 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: After holding a preliminary discussion with the parties the companyciliation officer examined the four demands made by the respondents and admitted into companyciliation only two of them they were in respect of the classification of certain employees and the bonus for the year 1952-53 the two remaining demands were number admitted in companyciliation.

facts.text: Conciliation proceedings infructuous, conciliation officer made failure report on July 5, 1954 under s.12(4).

anchor.surface_text: The companyciliation proceedings initiated by the companyciliator, however, proved infructuous with the result that on July 5, 1954, the companyciliator made his failure report under s. 12 4  of the Act.

facts.text: Government of Bombay considered matter, decided dispute should not be referred to industrial tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of this report the Government of Bombay  number the Government of Maharashtra  companysidered the matter and came to the companyclusion that the dispute in question should number be referred to an industrial tribunal for its adjudication.

facts.text: Government communicated decision on December 11, 1954 to respondents, reason: workmen resorted to go slow during 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, as required by s. 12 5  on December 11, 1954, the Government companymunicated to the respondents the said decision and stated that it does number propose to refer the said dispute to the tribunal under s. 12 5  for the reason that the workmen resorted to go slow during the year 1952-53.

facts.text: Respondents filed petition in Bombay High Court on February 18, 1955 under Art. 226 for writ of mandamus against State of Maharashtra to refer dispute.

anchor.surface_text: On February 18, 1955, the respondents filed in the Bombay High Court a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying for the issue of a writ of mandamus or a writ in the nature of mandamus or other writ, direction or order against the State of Maharashtra  hereafter called the appellant  calling upon it to refer the said dispute for industrial adjudication under s. 10 1  and s. 12 5  of the Act.

facts.text: Company impleaded as opponent in High Court petition.

anchor.surface_text: To this application the companypany was also impleaded as an opponent.

facts.text: Tendolkar J. held s.12(5) imposes obligation to refer if satisfied case made, reason extraneous, directed mandamus to reconsider ignoring go-slow.

anchor.surface_text: This petition was heard by Tendolkar J. He held that s. 12 5  in substance imposed an obligation on the appellant to refer the dispute provided it was satisfied that a case for reference had been made, and he came to the companyclusion that the reason given by the appellant for refusing to make a reference was so extraneous that the respondents were entitled to a writ of mandamus against the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant (State) and company preferred appeals, consolidated, heard by Chagla C.J. and Desai J., dismissed confirming writ.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision the appellant as well as the companypany preferred appeals. Chagla, C.J., and Desai, J., who companystituted the Court of Appeal, allowed the two appeals to be companysolidated, heard them together and came to the companyclusion that the view taken by Tendolkar J. was right and that the writ of mandamus had been properly issued against the appellant.

facts.text: State and company obtained certificate, appealed to Supreme Court as appeals Nos. 37 and 38 of 1957, consolidated.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and the companypany then applied for and obtained a certificate from the High Court and with that certificate they have companye to this Court by their two appeals Nos. 37 and 38 of 1957. These appeals have been ordered to be companysolidated and have been heard together,

facts.text: Common ground that during part of relevant year respondents adopted go-slow tactics; company says 7 months, respondents 5 months.

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with the said question it would be companyvenient to state one more relevant fact. It is companymon ground that during a part of the relevant year the respondents had adopted go-slow tactics. According to the companypany the period of go-slow attitude was seven months whereas according to the respondents it was about five months.

facts.text: Under clause 23(c) of standing orders, willful slowing-down amounts to misconduct; disciplinary action taken against 58 workmen.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that under clause 23 c  of the standing orders of the companypany willful slowing-down in performance of work, or abatement, or instigation thereof, amounts to misconduct, and it is number denied that as a result of the go-slow tactics adopted by the respondents disciplinary action was taken against 58 workmen employed by the companypany.

facts.text: Despite go-slow, total production comparable to previous years, profits justify additional bonus (respondents' case).

anchor.surface_text: The respondents case is that despite the go-slow strategy adopted by them for some months during the relevant year the total production for the said period companypares very favourably with the production for previous years and that the profit made by the companypany during the relevant year fully justifies their claim for additional bonus.

facts.text: Conciliation officer observed considerable substance in respondents' case for additional bonus.

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally the companyciliator observed that it appeared to him that there was companysiderable substance in the case made out by the respondents for payment of additional bonus.

facts.text: Conciliation officer opined classification demand consonant with practice in comparable concerns.

anchor.surface_text: The companyciliator also dealt with the respondents demand for classification and expressed his opinion that having regard to the type and nature of the work which was done by the workmen in question it seemed clear that the said work was mainly of a clerical nature and the demand that the said workmen should be taken on the monthly-paid roll appeared to be in companysonance with the practice prevailing in other companyparable companycerns.

facts.text: Company paid three months bonus for relevant year notwithstanding go-slow.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case it is significant that the companypany has voluntarily paid three months bonus for the relevant year numberwithstanding the fact that the workmen had adopted go-slow tactics during the year,

anchor.surface_text: In the result we companyfirm the order passed by the High Court though number exactly for the same reasons.

issues.text: short and interesting question about the construction of s. 12(5) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: construction of s. 12 5  of the Industrial Disputes Act 14 of 1947  hereafter called the Act . It appears that the respondents addressed four demands to the companypany they were in respect of gratuity, holidays, classification of certain employees and for the payment of an unconditional bonus for the financial year ended October 31, 1953.

issues.text: whether the validity of the order passed by the appellant refusing to refer the dispute for adjudication under s. 12(5) can be sustained

anchor.surface_text: under clause 23 c  of the standing orders of the companypany willful slowing-down in performance of work, or abatement, or instigation thereof, amounts to misconduct, and it is number denied that as a result of the go-slow tactics adopted by the respondents disciplinary action was taken against 58 workmen employed by the companypany. The respondents case is that despite the go-slow strategy adopted by them for some months during the relevant year the total production for the said period companypares very favourably with the production for previous years and that the profit made by the companypany during the relevant year fully justifies their claim for additional bonus. The appellant has taken the view that because the respondents adopted go-slow strategy during the relevant year the industrial dispute raised by them in regard to bonus as well as classification was number to be referred for adjudication under s. 12 5 . It is in the light of these facts that we have to companysider whether the validity of the order passed by the appellant refusing to refer the dispute for adjudication under s. 12 5  can be sustained.

holdings.text: Section 12(5) does not confer independent power to make reference; any reference must be under Section 10(1).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore it would number be reasonable to hold that s. 12 5  by itself and independently of s. 10 1  companyfers power on the appropriate Government to make a reference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of Chapter III; powers under s.10(3)-(7) apply only to s.10(1) references; avoids anomalous results like inability to prohibit strikes.

holdings.text: While acting under s.12(5), government not bound solely to s.12(4) report; may consider other relevant facts.

anchor.surface_text: but the words of s. 12 5  do number suggest that the report is the only material on which Government must base its conclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading; background of s.12 requires careful consideration of report but not exclusive; discretion under s.10(1) applies.

holdings.text: Discretion under s.12(5)/s.10(1) wide but must be exercised bona fide on relevant/material facts; reasons for refusal must be recorded and communicated.

anchor.surface_text: Naturally this wide discretion has to be exercised by the Government bona fide and on a companysideration of relevant and material facts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inherent in statutory scheme; coupled with duty to record reasons; analogous to s.10(1).

holdings.text: Writ of mandamus lies against refusal under s.12(5) if reasons not recorded/communicated, not bona fide, based on irrelevant/extraneous considerations.

anchor.surface_text: if the court is satisfied that the reasons given by the Government for refusing to make a reference are extraneous and number germane then the court can issue, and would be justified in issuing, a writ of mandamus even in respect of such an administrative order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common ground between parties; applies even to administrative orders if extraneous reasons; judicial review limited but available for irrelevance.

holdings.text: Reasons under s.12(5) must be germane/relevant; go-slow misconduct extraneous/punitive for bonus/classification claims.

anchor.surface_text: the impugned decision of the Government is wholly punitive in character and must in the circumstances be treated as based on a companysideration which is number germane and is extraneous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Go-slow irrelevant to merits (conciliator found substance, company paid bonus); punitive, not expediency; no bearing on classification benefiting employees.

holdings.text: Go-slow reason not germane in facts of case; mandamus properly issued.

anchor.surface_text: whether the reason given by the appellant in the present case for refusing to make a reference is germane or number.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application to facts: prima facie case (report, company payment); misconduct disciplined separately; bonus principles entitle share in profits.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we companyfirm the order passed by the High Court though number exactly for the same reasons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasons extraneous; mandamus directs reconsideration on germane grounds.

precedents.cited_proposition: in public statutes, words only directory, permissory or enabling may have a compulsory force where the thing to be done is for the public benefit or in advancement of public justice
precedents.cited_holding: The words undoubtedly are only empowering but it has been so often decided as to have become an axiom, that, in public statutes, words only directory, permissory or enabling may have a compulsory force where the thing to be done is for the public benefit or in advancement of public justice.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we confirm the order passed by the High Court though not exactly for the same reasons.

outcome.relief_summary: Confirmed the High Court order issuing writ of mandamus to the State to reconsider refusal to refer industrial dispute under s.12(5), holding the go-slow reason extraneous and punitive.
